New Records: Alek Thomas became the sixth player in LCS history to hit a pinch-hit game-tying home run.
Kyle Schwarber's fourth-inning homer was the 19th of his postseason career, the most ever by a left-handed hitter, passing Hall of Famer Reggie Jackson.
Trea Turner was caught stealing for the first time all season, ending a 40-game streak without being caught, tied with Jimmy Rollins (2007-08) for the third-longest span in major league history.
Key Match Events: A dramatic eighth-inning pinch-hit homer by Alek Thomas and RBI single by Gabriel Moreno gave the Arizona Diamondbacks three runs in the bottom of the eighth, propelling them to a come-from-behind 6–5 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies.
The Phillies unraveled in the top of the sixth, with rookie southpaw Andrew Saalfrank walking Schwarber, Turner, and Harper to load the bases.
The Diamondbacks extended their lead in the bottom of the third, with second baseman Ketel Marte leading off with an infield single to the shortstop and advancing to second on a wild pitch.
Pre-Game Insights: Manager Rob Thomson said in his pregame media session that Cristopher Sanchez was a starter, but he did not survive the third inning, forcing the Phillies to empty their 'pen.
Post-Match Reflections: Diamondbacks manager Torey Lovullo said in his postgame media session, “We’re in the middle of a journey. It’s a three-game series. We’re not going to lose focus. We are going to keep that competitive edge and that competitive focus. I can guarantee you that.”
Closer Paul Sewald said, “I don’t think I’ve ever heard a stadium that loud. That was electric.”
Craig Kimbrel said, “The last two games sucked. I rolled up in here and cost us two games. But the bright side is it’s still tied, 2–2.”
Miscellaneous Highlights: The game was a “bullpen game” for the Diamondbacks that worked out in their favor.
The Phillies and Diamondbacks used eight pitchers each, but the Phillies were not using starter Cristopher Sanchez as an opener.
The crowd went nuts as the opening strains of House of Pain’s “Jump Around” echoed through Chase Field.
Others: Kevin Ginkel pitched around a leadoff single to left by Bohm, holding the Phillies scoreless in the top of the eighth.
Ginkel recorded a scoreless frame without the benefit of a strikeout, ending a streak of 18 straight appearances with a strikeout.
